Title: Lansky
Produced by:
Robert Ogden Barnum 
 Lee Broda 
 Jeff Hoffman
Starring:
Harvey Keitel 
 Sam Worthington 
 AnnaSophia Robb 
 Minka Kelly 
 David James Elliott 
 John Magaro
Plot: When the aging Meyer Lansky is investigated one last time by the Feds, who suspect he has stashed away millions of dollars over half a century, the retired gangster spins a dizzying tale, revealing the untold truth about his life as the notorious boss of Murder, Inc. and the National Crime Syndicate.
Cast:
Harvey Keitel as Meyer Lansky
John Magaro as Young Meyer Lansky
John Magaro as Young Meyer Lansky

Dodge Prince as Young Buddy Lansky
Beau Hart as Child Buddy Lansky
Beau Hart as Child Buddy Lansky
David James Elliott as Frank Rivers
James Moses Black as R.J. Campbell
Danny A. Abeckaser as Greg Kunz
Production: In May 2019, it was announced Harvey Keitel, Sam Worthington, Emory Cohen and Austin Stowell had joined the cast of the film, with Alexandra Daddario and Tony Danza in negotiations to join with Eytan Rockaway directing from a screenplay he wrote. In February 2020, it was announced AnnaSophia Robb, Jackie Cruz, John Magaro, David Cade, David James Elliott, Alon Abutbul and Minka Kelly had joined the cast of the film, with Cohen, Stowell, Daddario and Danza no longer attached.
Principal photography lasted 20 days in Alabama in February 2020.
Release: In May 2021, Vertical Entertainment acquired distribution rights to the film, and set it for a theatrical and on VOD release on June 25, 2021.
Reception: On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 62% of 45 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 6.10/10. On Metacritic, the film has a weighted average score of 45 out of 100, based on seven critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".

Joe Leydon from Variety wrote  "Keitel [...] infuses his performance here with more than enough lion-in-winter gravitas to dominate every moment he is on screen, and quite a few when he isn't." Richard Roeper from Chicago Sun Times said "Harvey Keitel takes a swing at portraying the 'Mob's Accountant' and Keitel is as reliable as he's always been - but while this is a well-filmed and well-acted story, much of the material has been covered in superior movies."
